metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: compare Einstein's special theory of relativity with the principles of classical physics

absolute_vs_relative_spacetime.name: Absolute vs Relative Space and Time
absolute_vs_relative_spacetime.correct: Classical physics treats space and time as absolute (same for all observers). Special relativity shows they are relative (depend on the observer's reference frame).

both treat space and time as absolute.error: Only classical physics treats space and time as absolute.
both treat space and time as absolute.fix: Special relativity fundamentally changed this by showing length and time measurements depend on the observer's reference frame.
both treat space and time as absolute.action: Consider: if all observers agree on the speed of light, something else must change. That something is space and time.

both treat space and time as relative.error: Classical physics treats space and time as absolute.
both treat space and time as relative.fix: Newton and classical physicists assumed all observers would agree on length and time measurements. Einstein showed this is only an approximation.
both treat space and time as relative.action: Compare: classical physics predicts identical clocks stay synchronised forever. Relativity says moving clocks run slower.

classical treats them as relative.fix: Classical physics assumes absolute space and time. Relativity introduced the frame-dependent nature of measurements.
classical treats them as relative.action: Remember: Einstein's theory was revolutionary precisely because it challenged the classical assumption of absolute time.

persistent.gap: You do not understand the fundamental difference in how space and time are treated.
persistent.action: Study: Classical physics says a metre is a metre everywhere. Relativity says a moving object is length-contracted.

time_measurement_frames.name: Time Measurements Between Frames
time_measurement_frames.correct: In special relativity, observers in different reference frames measure different time intervals between the same events. Moving clocks run slower (time dilation).

all observers agree on time.error: That is the classical physics prediction, not relativity.
all observers agree on time.fix: Special relativity shows time is relative. A moving clock runs slower than a stationary one.
all observers agree on time.action: Calculate: if γ = 2, a clock moving relative to you ticks half as fast.

time only differs for accelerating frame.error: Time dilation occurs between any two inertial frames with relative motion.
time only differs for accelerating frame.fix: Special relativity applies to inertial (non-accelerating) frames. Moving at constant velocity still causes time dilation.
time only differs for accelerating frame.action: Muons created in the upper atmosphere reach Earth because their internal clocks run slower relative to Earth.

time differences are measurement errors.error: Time dilation is a real physical effect, not an experimental error.
time differences are measurement errors.fix: The effect has been confirmed by atomic clocks on aircraft and GPS satellites.
time differences are measurement errors.action: GPS satellites must correct for time dilation. Without this, positioning would drift by kilometres per day.

persistent.gap: You are treating time dilation as either a classical concept or an error.
persistent.action: Study the muon decay experiment: muons should decay before reaching Earth, but time dilation extends their observed lifetime.

length_measurement_frames.name: Length Measurements Between Frames
length_measurement_frames.correct: In special relativity, an object moving relative to an observer is measured to be shorter along the direction of motion (length contraction).

all observers agree on length.error: That is the classical physics prediction.
all observers agree on length.fix: Special relativity shows that moving objects are length-contracted along the direction of motion.
all observers agree on length.action: If a rocket travels at 0.8c relative to you, you measure it as 60% of its proper length.

moving objects appear longer.fix: Length contraction makes moving objects shorter, not longer. L = L₀/γ, where γ > 1.
moving objects appear longer.action: Since γ is always greater than 1 for moving objects, L₀/γ is always less than L₀.

length changes in all directions.error: Length contraction only occurs along the direction of motion.
length changes in all directions.fix: A moving object is contracted only in the direction of travel. Perpendicular dimensions are unchanged.
length changes in all directions.action: A spaceship moving horizontally at high speed appears shorter horizontally but the same height vertically.

persistent.gap: You are not correctly applying the concept of length contraction.
persistent.action: Draw diagrams showing the same spaceship from the pilot's view (proper length) and from a ground observer's view (contracted).

speed_of_light_classical.name: Speed of Light in Classical Physics
speed_of_light_classical.formula: Classical: c + v or c − v (relative velocities add)
speed_of_light_classical.correct: Classical physics predicts light speed should change based on observer motion. An observer moving toward a light source should measure a higher speed.

classical physics says c is constant.error: No, that is Einstein's postulate, not classical physics.
classical physics says c is constant.fix: Classical physics treats light like any other wave, with speeds that add or subtract based on relative motion.
classical physics says c is constant.action: Classical prediction: moving toward a light beam at 0.5c should give measured speed = 1.5c.

classical physics says nothing about lig.error: Classical physics includes Maxwell's equations and Galilean relativity.
classical physics says nothing about lig.fix: Classical physics predicts relative velocities should add, so light speed should depend on observer motion.
classical physics says nothing about lig.action: The contradiction between Maxwell (constant c) and Galileo (additive velocities) led to relativity.

classical physics predicts c = 0 for mov.error: No, classical physics predicts c changes, not that it becomes zero.
classical physics predicts c = 0 for mov.fix: Moving toward light: measured speed = c + v. Moving away: measured speed = c − v.
classical physics predicts c = 0 for mov.action: Think about catching a ball thrown at you while running toward the thrower. You measure higher ball speed.

persistent.gap: You are confusing classical predictions with relativistic predictions about light speed.
persistent.action: Make a comparison table: what each theory predicts for measured light speed with different observer motions.

speed_of_light_relativity.name: Speed of Light in Special Relativity
speed_of_light_relativity.correct: Einstein's second postulate states the speed of light in a vacuum is the same (c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s) for all observers, regardless of their motion or the motion of the source.

c changes with observer motion.error: That is the classical prediction. Relativity says c is constant.
c changes with observer motion.fix: This is Einstein's revolutionary insight: all observers measure c, regardless of their motion.
c changes with observer motion.action: Whether you move toward or away from a light beam, you always measure c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s.

c is constant only in a vacuum.error: While c refers to vacuum speed, the principle applies to all electromagnetic waves in vacuum.
c is constant only in a vacuum.fix: The postulate specifically states the speed of light in a vacuum is constant for all observers.
c is constant only in a vacuum.action: This is experimentally verified: the Michelson-Morley experiment showed no change in light speed with Earth's motion.

c depends on the light source velocity.error: The speed of light is independent of source motion.
c depends on the light source velocity.fix: Whether the source moves toward or away from you, you measure the same speed of light.
c depends on the light source velocity.action: A star moving toward Earth emits light that arrives at exactly c, not c + star's velocity.

persistent.gap: You are not accepting Einstein's second postulate.
persistent.action: Review the Michelson-Morley experiment: it showed light speed is the same regardless of Earth's orbital direction.

galilean_velocity_addition.name: Galilean (Classical) Velocity Addition
galilean_velocity_addition.correct: Classical physics uses Galilean velocity addition: relative velocities simply add together. If you walk at 5 km/h on a train moving at 100 km/h, your speed relative to ground is 105 km/h.

velocities do not add in classical physi.error: Galilean relativity clearly states velocities add linearly.
velocities do not add in classical physi.fix: Classical physics predicts v_total = v₁ + v₂ without any upper limit.
velocities do not add in classical physi.action: In everyday life, this works: walking on a train, throwing a ball from a moving car.

classical physics has a speed limit.error: Classical physics has no speed limit. Only relativity introduces c as a limit.
classical physics has a speed limit.fix: Classical physics allows any speed: 2c, 10c, 1000c would all be possible.
classical physics has a speed limit.action: This is why classical physics fails at high speeds. It predicts speeds exceeding c.

velocities multiply in classical physics.error: No, Galilean transformation uses addition, not multiplication.
velocities multiply in classical physics.fix: v_relative = v₁ + v₂ (or v₁ − v₂ depending on directions).
velocities multiply in classical physics.action: Two cars approaching each other at 60 km/h: relative speed = 60 + 60 = 120 km/h (classical).

persistent.gap: You are not correctly stating Galilean velocity addition.
persistent.action: Practice: calculate relative velocities for everyday scenarios using simple addition.

relativistic_velocity_addition.name: Relativistic Velocity Addition
relativistic_velocity_addition.formula: Velocities don't simply add; c is never exceeded
relativistic_velocity_addition.correct: In special relativity, velocities do not add linearly. The relativistic formula ensures that no relative velocity can exceed c, even if both objects travel at high fractions of c.

velocities still add linearly.fix: Relativistic velocity addition ensures the sum never exceeds c.
velocities still add linearly.action: Two rockets at 0.6c toward each other: classical says 1.2c, relativity says 0.88c.

only light travels at c.error: True, but the point is no relative velocity exceeds c either.
only light travels at c.fix: Even the relative speed between two objects, each moving at 0.99c, cannot exceed c.
only light travels at c.action: This is a consequence of length contraction and time dilation.

velocities subtract instead of add.error: Velocities still combine, just not linearly.
velocities subtract instead of add.fix: The relativistic formula accounts for both velocities but prevents exceeding c.
velocities subtract instead of add.action: The formula is complex, but the key outcome is: no relative velocity exceeds c.

persistent.gap: You do not understand why velocities cannot simply add at relativistic speeds.
persistent.action: Remember: if velocities added normally at high speeds, relative velocities could exceed c, violating the second postulate.

classical_kinetic_energy.name: Classical Kinetic Energy
classical_kinetic_energy.correct: Classical physics calculates kinetic energy as KE = ½mv². This formula works well at low speeds but underestimates energy at speeds approaching c.

KE = mv².fix: Classical kinetic energy is KE = ½mv², not mv².
KE = mv².action: Derive from work-energy theorem: W = ∫F·dx gives ½mv².

KE = ½mv.fix: KE = ½mv². Doubling speed quadruples kinetic energy.
KE = ½mv.action: Check units: ½ × kg × (m/s)² = kg·m²/s² = J.

classical KE has no formula.error: Classical physics absolutely has a kinetic energy formula.
classical KE has no formula.fix: KE = ½mv² is the standard Newtonian kinetic energy formula.
classical KE has no formula.action: This works perfectly for everyday speeds, just not near c.

persistent.gap: You need to memorise the classical kinetic energy formula.
persistent.action: Write KE = ½mv² ten times. Calculate KE for various masses and speeds.

relativistic_kinetic_energy.name: Relativistic Kinetic Energy
relativistic_kinetic_energy.correct: Relativistic kinetic energy is KE = (γ − 1)mc². As v approaches c, γ approaches infinity, so KE approaches infinity. This is why massive objects cannot reach c.

KE = γmc².error: That is total energy, not kinetic energy.
KE = γmc².fix: Total energy E = γmc². Kinetic energy = E − E₀ = γmc² − mc² = (γ − 1)mc².
KE = γmc².action: Remember: KE is the extra energy above rest mass energy.

same as classical.error: They only agree at low speeds where γ ≈ 1.
same as classical.fix: At high speeds, relativistic KE is much larger than classical ½mv².
same as classical.action: Compare: at 0.9c, classical gives ≈ 0.4mc², relativistic gives ≈ 1.3mc².

KE decreases as speed increases.fix: Both classical and relativistic KE increase with speed. Relativistic just increases much faster near c.
KE decreases as speed increases.action: As v → c, γ → ∞, so KE → ∞.

persistent.gap: You are confusing relativistic KE with total energy or classical KE.
persistent.action: Study: E_total = γmc², E_rest = mc², KE = (γ − 1)mc². Know all three formulas.

ke_comparison.name: Comparing Classical and Relativistic KE
ke_comparison.formula: At v << c: both agree. At v → c: relativistic >> classical
ke_comparison.correct: At low speeds, classical and relativistic KE give nearly identical results. As speed approaches c, relativistic KE becomes much larger than classical KE.

classical KE is always larger.error: The opposite is true at high speeds.
classical KE is always larger.fix: Relativistic KE is always larger than or equal to classical KE.
classical KE is always larger.action: Calculate: at 0.99c, classical gives ≈ 0.49mc², relativistic gives ≈ 6.1mc².

they never agree.error: They agree very closely at low speeds.
they never agree.fix: At low speeds (v << c), γ ≈ 1 + ½v²/c², so (γ − 1)mc² ≈ ½mv².
they never agree.action: This is why classical physics works for everyday speeds.

relativistic KE is always infinite.error: KE is only infinite at v = c. At any v < c, it is finite.
relativistic KE is always infinite.fix: KE increases dramatically as v approaches c but only reaches infinity at exactly c.
relativistic KE is always infinite.action: At 0.5c, γ = 1.15, so KE = 0.15mc². Large but not infinite.

persistent.gap: You do not understand when classical and relativistic predictions differ.
persistent.action: Graph both KE formulas from 0 to 0.99c. Note where they diverge significantly.

speed_limit_classical.name: Speed Limits in Classical Physics
speed_limit_classical.correct: Classical physics has no maximum speed. Given enough force and time, an object could theoretically accelerate to any speed, including speeds greater than c.

classical physics limits speed to c.error: No, only relativity introduces c as a speed limit.
classical physics limits speed to c.fix: Classical physics allows unlimited speeds. That is why it fails at high speeds.
classical physics limits speed to c.action: According to F = ma, constant force gives constant acceleration forever, reaching any speed.

classical physics limits speed to 0.99c.error: Classical physics has no speed limit whatsoever.
classical physics limits speed to 0.99c.fix: Any value like 0.99c, c, 2c, etc., is theoretically achievable in classical physics.
classical physics limits speed to 0.99c.action: The lack of a speed limit is a fundamental flaw in classical physics.

speed is limited by available energy.error: In classical physics, speed grows proportionally with energy input.
speed is limited by available energy.fix: KE = ½mv² has no upper limit. More energy = more speed, without bound.
speed is limited by available energy.action: Relativistically, approaching c requires infinite energy. Classically, it just requires more energy.

persistent.gap: You are imposing relativistic constraints on classical physics.
persistent.action: Study classical predictions: if F = ma with constant F, then v = at, unbounded.

speed_limit_relativity.name: Speed Limit in Special Relativity
speed_limit_relativity.formula: v < c for all massive objects
speed_limit_relativity.correct: In special relativity, no massive object can reach or exceed the speed of light. As v approaches c, the required energy approaches infinity.

objects can exceed c with enough energy.error: No amount of energy can accelerate a massive object to c.
objects can exceed c with enough energy.fix: KE = (γ − 1)mc² approaches infinity as v → c. You would need infinite energy.
objects can exceed c with enough energy.action: Particle accelerators demonstrate this: particles approach but never reach c.

only light is limited to c.error: All objects with mass are limited to speeds less than c.
only light is limited to c.fix: Light travels AT c because photons are massless. Massive objects can only approach c asymptotically.
only light is limited to c.action: Electrons in accelerators can reach 0.9999c but never exactly c.

the speed limit is an engineering proble.error: It is a fundamental physical limit, not a technological one.
the speed limit is an engineering proble.fix: The speed limit arises from the structure of spacetime itself, not our technology.
the speed limit is an engineering proble.action: Even with perfect efficiency and unlimited energy, massive objects cannot reach c.

persistent.gap: You do not understand why c is an absolute limit for massive objects.
persistent.action: Study: as v → c, γ → ∞, so both time dilation and energy become infinite.

space_time.title: Space and Time: Classical vs Relativistic
space_time.instructions: Complete the statements comparing how classical physics and special relativity treat space and time.

sentences.text: Classical physics assumes space and time are {{d1}}, meaning all observers should agree on measurements of {{d2}} and {{d3}} regardless of their relative motion.

d1.tooltip: Newton assumed all clocks tick the same everywhere. What term describes this?

d2.tooltip: One of the two quantities that change between reference frames in relativity.

d3.tooltip: The other quantity that differs between moving reference frames.

sentences.text: Special relativity shows that measurements of time and length depend on the {{d4}} of the observer. Moving clocks run {{d5}} and moving objects are {{d6}} along the direction of motion.

d4.tooltip: What changes between observers in relative motion?

d5.tooltip: Time dilation: moving clocks tick less frequently.

d6.tooltip: Length contraction reduces the length along the direction of motion.

light_speed.title: The Speed of Light
light_speed.instructions: Complete the statements about how classical physics and special relativity treat the speed of light.

sentences.text: Classical physics predicts the measured speed of light should {{d1}} based on the observer's motion. An observer moving toward a light source should measure a speed {{d2}} than c.

d1.tooltip: Classical physics treats light like any projectile, with relative velocities.

d2.tooltip: Moving toward a source should add velocities classically.

sentences.text: Einstein's second postulate states that the speed of light in a vacuum is {{d3}} for all observers, regardless of the motion of the {{d4}} or the {{d5}}.

d3.tooltip: The revolutionary idea: light speed is the same for everyone.

d4.tooltip: Your motion does not affect your measurement of light speed.

d5.tooltip: The light source's motion also does not affect the measured speed.

sentences.text: The {{d6}} experiment measured no change in light speed despite Earth's motion, supporting Einstein's postulate and contradicting {{d7}} predictions.

d6.tooltip: This experiment tried to detect Earth's motion through the aether.

d7.tooltip: Which type of physics predicted light speed would change?

velocity_addition.title: Adding Velocities
velocity_addition.instructions: Complete the statements about velocity addition in classical and relativistic physics.

sentences.text: Classical physics uses {{d1}} velocity addition, where relative velocities simply {{d2}}. If two objects approach each other at 0.6c each, classical physics predicts a relative speed of {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: Named after the scientist who first described relative motion.

sentences.text: In special relativity, velocities {{d4}} add linearly. The relativistic formula ensures that no relative velocity can {{d5}}. For the same scenario, relativity predicts approximately {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: The speed of light is an absolute limit.

d6.tooltip: The relativistic formula gives a result less than c.

kinetic_energy.title: Kinetic Energy Formulas
kinetic_energy.instructions: Complete the statements comparing kinetic energy in classical and relativistic physics.

sentences.text: Classical physics calculates kinetic energy using KE = {{d1}}. This formula predicts that kinetic energy can increase {{d2}} without any upper limit.

d1.tooltip: The standard Newtonian kinetic energy formula.

d2.tooltip: Classical physics has no speed limit, so no energy limit.

sentences.text: Relativistic kinetic energy is calculated using KE = {{d3}}. As velocity approaches c, the Lorentz factor γ approaches {{d4}}, so the required kinetic energy approaches {{d5}}.

d3.tooltip: Subtract rest energy from total energy.

d5.tooltip: This is why massive objects cannot reach c.

sentences.text: At {{d6}} speeds, classical and relativistic formulas give nearly identical results. At high speeds, the relativistic value is always {{d7}} than the classical value.

d7.tooltip: Relativistic effects always increase the energy required.

space_time.title: Applying Space and Time Concepts
space_time.instructions: Apply your understanding of space and time in classical and relativistic contexts.

sentences.text: A scientist on Earth measures a spacecraft's length as 80 m, while the pilot measures it as 100 m. The pilot's measurement is the {{d1}}, and the Earth observer measures a {{d2}} length because the spacecraft is {{d3}} relative to Earth.

d1.tooltip: The measurement in the object's rest frame.

d2.tooltip: Moving objects appear shorter to stationary observers.

d3.tooltip: Length contraction occurs due to relative motion.

sentences.text: GPS satellites must account for {{d4}} effects. Clocks on the satellites run at a {{d5}} rate than ground clocks due to their orbital velocity. Without corrections, positioning errors would accumulate to {{d6}} per day.

d4.tooltip: Moving clocks run slower than stationary ones.

d5.tooltip: Special relativistic time dilation slows moving clocks.

d6.tooltip: The cumulative error would be substantial without correction.

light_speed.title: Light Speed in Different Scenarios
light_speed.instructions: Apply concepts about light speed to various scenarios.

sentences.text: A spaceship travels at 0.9c toward a star that emits light. The pilot measures the light approaching at {{d1}}. Classical physics would incorrectly predict the light approaches at {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Einstein's postulate: all observers measure c.

sentences.text: The Michelson-Morley experiment compared light beams travelling {{d3}} to Earth's orbital motion. If the aether existed, beams in different directions would have {{d4}} speeds. The {{d5}} showed light speed was the same in all directions.

d3.tooltip: The interferometer had arms at 90 degrees.

d4.tooltip: The aether would cause a 'headwind' or 'crosswind' effect.

d5.tooltip: No difference was found, disproving the aether hypothesis.

velocity_addition.title: Velocity Addition Applications
velocity_addition.instructions: Apply velocity addition concepts to practical scenarios.

sentences.text: A person walks at 5 km/h on a train moving at 100 km/h. Classical physics gives a ground speed of {{d1}}. At everyday speeds, this agrees with {{d2}} because velocities are much {{d3}} than c.

d2.tooltip: Both theories agree at low speeds.

d3.tooltip: Everyday speeds are a tiny fraction of c.

sentences.text: Particle accelerators demonstrate relativistic velocity limits. As a proton approaches c, adding more energy increases its speed by {{d4}} amounts. The proton's velocity can approach but never {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: Returns diminish as you approach c.

d5.tooltip: c is an asymptotic limit for massive particles.

sentences.text: Classical physics fails because it predicts relative velocities can {{d6}} the speed of light. Special relativity ensures all relative velocities remain {{d7}} c.

d6.tooltip: Classical addition has no upper limit.

d7.tooltip: The relativistic formula enforces this limit.

kinetic_energy.title: Kinetic Energy Applications
kinetic_energy.instructions: Apply kinetic energy concepts to relativistic scenarios.

sentences.text: An electron accelerated to 0.99c has a Lorentz factor γ ≈ 7.1. Its relativistic KE is {{d1}} times its rest mass energy. Classical physics would predict only {{d2}} times the rest mass energy.
At relativistic speeds, more energy input produces {{d3}} increase in speed. This is because an increasing fraction of energy goes into {{d4}} rather than {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: The effective mass increases with velocity.

space_time.title: Mastering Space-Time Concepts
space_time.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of the differences between classical and relativistic treatments of space and time.

sentences.text: The fundamental reason space and time must be relative in Einstein's theory is that the {{d1}} must be constant. Since speed equals distance divided by time, and c cannot change, {{d2}} must change between reference frames.

d1.tooltip: What is constant for all observers in relativity?

d2.tooltip: c = d/t. If c is fixed, d and t must be flexible.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that relativistic effects are only relevant at {{d3}}. In reality, time dilation and length contraction occur at {{d4}}, but are only measurable at speeds approaching {{d5}}.

d3.tooltip: When do we typically notice relativistic effects?

d4.tooltip: The effects exist even at low speeds, just immeasurably small.

d5.tooltip: Relativistic effects become significant as v approaches c.

sentences.text: Classical physics is not {{d6}}, just {{d7}}. It remains accurate for everyday applications where v << c.

d6.tooltip: Classical physics is a limiting case of relativity.

d7.tooltip: It works perfectly at low speeds.

light_speed.title: Light Speed: The Ultimate Constant
light_speed.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of the role of light speed in relativity.

sentences.text: The constancy of c is not merely an experimental result but a {{d1}} of special relativity. All relativistic effects (time dilation, length contraction, mass-energy equivalence) follow from this {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Einstein assumed this as a starting point.

d2.tooltip: The postulates are the foundation of the theory.

sentences.text: The conflict between Maxwell's equations (predicting {{d3}} light speed) and Galilean relativity (predicting {{d4}} velocities) led Einstein to question {{d5}} physics.

d3.tooltip: Maxwell's equations give c as a constant.

d4.tooltip: Galilean relativity says velocities simply add.

d5.tooltip: Einstein challenged the assumptions of pre-1905 physics.

velocity_addition.title: Velocity Addition: Classical vs Relativistic
velocity_addition.instructions: Synthesise your understanding of how velocities combine in each theory.

sentences.text: The key insight is that relativistic velocity addition reduces to {{d1}} addition at low speeds. When v << c, the correction factor is approximately {{d2}}, giving nearly {{d3}} results.

d1.tooltip: What type of addition does relativity approximate at low speeds?

d2.tooltip: The relativistic correction approaches 1 as v approaches 0.

d3.tooltip: Both theories agree when velocities are small compared to c.

sentences.text: A particle cannot be accelerated to c because doing so would require {{d4}} energy. This is fundamentally different from classical physics, which has {{d5}} on achievable speeds.
In particle accelerators, protons routinely reach {{d6}} of c. The energy required to go from 0.99c to 0.999c is {{d7}} than going from 0.9c to 0.99c, demonstrating the relativistic speed limit.

d6.tooltip: Modern accelerators achieve speeds very close to c.

d7.tooltip: Each increment closer to c requires exponentially more energy.

kinetic_energy.title: Complete Energy Comparison
kinetic_energy.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of energy concepts in classical and relativistic physics.

sentences.text: The relativistic formula KE = (γ − 1)mc² can be expanded for v << c to give KE ≈ {{d1}}, recovering the {{d2}} result. This shows relativity is a {{d3}} of classical physics.

d1.tooltip: What is the classical kinetic energy formula?

d2.tooltip: Relativity reduces to which physics at low speeds?

d3.tooltip: Relativity includes classical physics as a special case.

sentences.text: The failure of classical physics to predict correct energies at high speeds has practical consequences. Particle accelerator designs must use {{d4}} formulas because classical predictions would be {{d5}} by orders of magnitude.

d4.tooltip: Which formulas are needed for high-speed particles?

d5.tooltip: Classical physics drastically underestimates energy at high speeds.

sentences.text: A proton at 0.99c has relativistic KE about {{d6}} times larger than classical KE. This ratio {{d7}} as speed approaches c, demonstrating why the classical formula fails at high speeds.

d7.tooltip: The discrepancy grows larger as v approaches c.
